section.title: Definition
section.para: Contains a list of input repositories that System Studio uses to download packages for the repository.

When the value of is "system", System Studio requires at least one input repository. Repositories are specified using repo elements (see ). Valid repository definitions must include a minimum of one baseurl. Furthermore, all repositories must have a unique id.

section.title: Base Repositories
section.para: Also when the value of is "system", at least one of the input repositories must specify an operating system base repository containing install images and isolinux files. These files are located within folders called images and isolinux, respectively, and are used to create installation images for the system. Base repositories include CentOS base repositories, Red Hat Enterprise Linux base repositories, or any system repository created by System Studio. Multiple base repositories may be specified, making it possible to create new system repositories, for example, by starting with a System Studio created system repository and adding packages from compatible CentOS or RHEL base and update repositories.

For CentOS, and System Studio-created repositories, the base repository will be a public or local mirror. For Red Hat Enterprise Linux, it will be an install tree created by using the mount -o loop isofile mount_location command to mount an ISO image file to a local or web-available network location. See the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 Installation Guide under the topic Preparing for a Network Installation for more information.

section.title: Red Hat Network Repositories
section.para: System Studio supports connecting to and downloading packages from Red Hat Network (RHN) servers.

Prior to using System Studio to access updates from RHN you will need to create a systemid. This requires an available subscription to Red Hat Enterprise Linux. See the Red Hat web site for purchase information. Once you have an available subscription, install Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 in the desired architecture version (i386 or x86_64) onto a client machine. Register the machine to Red Hat Network during installation, or first boot, or later using the rhn_register command. Once the machine has successfully registered with RHN, a systemid file will be created in the /etc/sysconfig/ folder of the machine. This is the file you will use to configure System Studio to access software from RHN. You may copy this file to the System Studio build machine if necessary. Note, to ensure the systemid has access to the software desired for your repository, you can use the Red Hat Network web user interface to locate the machine, and view and alter its channel subscriptions.

In the above, $rhnhost is the hostname of the server to contact and $rhnchannel is the label of the RHN channel from which to obtain packages. If not specified, $rhnhost defaults to a public Red Hat Network server at xmlrpc.rhn.redhat.com. RHN channel labels can be located in the RHN web user interface by clicking the name of a channel. Common channel labels include the following:
rhel-i386-server-5 rhel-i386-server-vt-5 rhel-x86_64-server-5 rhel-x86_64-server-vt-5
Separate repositories must be defined for the base channel as well as for each child channel. See for an example.

section.title: Including and Excluding Repository Content
section.para: By default, all packages in all repositories are available for System Studio to use. Packages can be excluded from all repositories using the packages/exclude element. See the section on for information.

Available packages for a single repository can be restricted by using one or more repo/exclude or repo/include elements. The logic for processing these elements, described below, is the same as YUM's processing of include and exclude repo options.

Using a repository's repo/include elements, the list of available packages is restricted to only those packages that match one or more of the included PACKAGE patterns. If no repo/include patterns are specified, all packages are considered available.

After processing a repository's repo/include elements, the repo/exclude element can be used to selectively remove specific packages from the list of available packages for the repository. Any package matching one or more of the PACKAGE patterns specified in a repo/exclude element will be ignored by System Studio.
See for an example.

section.title: Repository Groups
section.para: System Studio supports an expanded type of repository, a "repository group". A repository group is a collection of standard YUM repositories within a single folder. This feature allows, for example, defining a Red Hat Enterprise Linux installation tree as a single repository when in fact it contain multiple repositories.
For example, if there are three repositories repoA, repoB, and repoC in folder /var/repos, all the repos can be included in System Studio using a repo group:
This repository contains all the packages available in each of the individual repositories repoA, repoB, and repoC.

section.title: Examples
section.para: In the following examples, line breaks have been added to the repos/repo/baseurl to improve readability. In a real repository definition, however, line breaks within PATH-like elements are not allowed.

section.title: Example 1 - using repos/repo/include and repos/repo/exclude
section.para: In the following example, two repositories are defined directly in XML. The first repository contains includes all packages except those that match the PACKAGE pattern "xorg-x11-drv*" while the second repository only includes packages that match the same pattern.
Additionally, System Studio will include any and all repositories defined in the file centos-extras.repo.

informalexample.programlisting:
<repos> <repo id="base"> <baseurl>http://mirror.centos.org/centos/%{version}/os/%{arch}/</baseurl>
<!-- exclude all xorg-x11-drv packages --> <exclude>xorg-x11-drv*</exclude> </repo>
<repo id="livna-drivers"> <baseurl>http://rpm.livna.org/repo/%{version}/%{arch}/<baseurl>
<!-- include only xorg-x11-drv packages --> <include>xorg-x11-drv*</include> </repo> </repos>

section.title: Example 2 - Red Hat Network repositories
section.para: Repositories that utilize the rhn protocol to contact the Red Hat Network require a systemid to be specified. See for more information on using Red Hat Network repositories.
